    <item>
      <title>How Silverstring Media  fought GamerGate and ADHD to make compelling games</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/silverstring-gamergate-adhd-compelling-games</link>
      <description><p>For four months, this Vancouver studio was at the centre of an internet maelstrom. But it had overcome bigger challenges </p><p><em>“Recent events have thrust our company under a spotlight …” </em>It was with those words, in September 2014, that Lucas J W Johnson, one of the founding members of Silverstring Media, began <a draggable="true" href="http://silverstringmedia.com/news/2014/9/1/intent-and-ideology">a blogpost about his company</a>. “Under a spotlight”, it turned out, was something of an understatement. Silverstring Media had been targeted by the burgeoning online movement GamerGate, a loose affiliation of Twitter, Reddit and game forums users claiming to expose and protest corruption in the video games media. The company was accused of being “corrupt” and “creepy”, supposedly pushing ideologies and cultish practices that worked towards taking “the fun out of video games”. Connections were established between Silverstring and the original GamerGate target <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jan/11/gamergate-a-brief-history-of-a-computer-age-war">Zoe Quinn</a>. Then everything snowballed.</p><p>“[GamerGaters] got it into their heads that Silverstring Media was a PR firm, and that as such we must have been behind a conspiracy to release a series of ‘<a href="http://kotaku.com/we-might-be-witnessing-the-death-of-an-identity-1628203079">gamers</a> <a href="http://dangolding.tumblr.com/post/95985875943/the-end-of-gamers">are</a> <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/josephbernstein/gaming-is-leaving-gamers-behind">dead</a>’ articles all at once from multiple different venues,” Johnson said. “As conspiracies do, that then spiralled into further corruption with the Digital Games Research Association (DiGRA), and eventually allegations that we work with the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa). We became ‘the final boss’ of GamerGate, responsible for all their woes.”</p><p>Storytelling is extremely important. Culture reshapes itself one piece of media at a time</p><p>More compassionate, more inclusive and more nuanced stories make a huge difference, especially for younger generations</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/silverstring-gamergate-adhd-compelling-games">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>When it comes to interracial romances, the movies need to catch up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up</link>
      <description><p>Almost 50 years after Kirk and Uhura’s kiss on Star Trek, there are plenty of parts for black women - provided they want to play blue- or green-skinned aliens …</p><p>“Interspecies love is in the air!” enthuses <a href="http://teaser-trailer.com/warcraft-movie-anduin-lothar-and-garona-halforcen/">one movie fansite</a> at the prospect of the forthcoming Warcraft movie.</p><p>There’s a lot to get up to speed with in Warcraft. The original video games were so wildly popular that their community of players exceeds the population of Norway, and the <a href="http://wowwiki.wikia.com/wiki/Portal:Main">World of Warcraft wiki</a> has over 100,000 pages. For novices, it’s a fantasy world not far removed from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/lord-of-the-rings">Lord of the Rings</a> or Dungeons and Dragons: a realm of elves, dwarves, mythical creatures and medieval weaponry. Warcraft the movie revolves around Azeroth, a kingdom apparently ruled by European humans. Azeroth is invaded by orcs: hulking, relatively primitive ogres with overdeveloped lower canines. Rather than open arms, Azeroth greets these refugee orcs with medieval arms. “They’re beasts. They should all be destroyed,” says one character. It’s essentially a race war, although the battle lines are by no means cut and dried, so there’s still room for a bit of interspecies love.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/08/oscars-so-white-diversity-issues-protests-sylvester-stallone-creed">Oscar nominees weigh in on lack of diversity: 'there’s an elephant in the room'</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/17/ruth-negga-hollywood-12-years-a-slave-misfits-preacher-iona-loving">Ruth Negga: ‘I never fitted anywhere – in&nbsp;life or in Hollywood’</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is the Assassin's Creed movie actually going to be good?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/assassins-creed-movie-michael-fassbender-good</link>
      <description><p>The first trailer was released on Wednesday, showing Michael Fassbender donning the assassin’s hood. It shows promise, but we’ve been here before</p><p>Video game movie adaptation. It’s a phrase likely to strike fear and dread into the heart of most gamers, and indeed most moviegoers. Street Fighter, Super Mario Bros, Silent Hill, Hitman. All of these classic, hugely acclaimed video games have been thrust onto the big screen (or the straight-to-DVD shelves) by people whose knowledge of the source materials seems to have been passing at best. The results have been ... horrible.</p><p>Assassin’s Creed, we are being told, is a different story. Produced by Ubisoft, the company that developed and published the bestselling games, it has actual star actors (Michael Fassbender, Marion Cotillard, Jeremy Irons) and a talented director in the form of Justin Kurzel, who made the award-winning Snowtown and helmed Fassbender’s gritty Macbeth movie. For once this isn’t a bunch of Hollywood chancers hoping to cash in on a successful gaming brand; it’s the game makers themselves, overseeing their vision as a motion picture spectacle. The Assassin’s Creed titles have apparently been referenced closely by the production team, with the prop makers studying 3D representations of every weapon and costume. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2015/aug/31/michael-fassbender-assassins-creed-video-game-movie">Can Michael Fassbender's Assassin's Creed save the video game movie?</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2007/nov/30/whyarevideogamebasedfilms">Why are video game-based films always so poor?</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/assassins-creed-movie-michael-fassbender-good">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Call of Duty maker Activision to use Facebook live video to push e-sports</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/call-of-duty-activision-facebook-esports-twitch-instagram</link>
      <description><p>World’s largest computer game publisher also hopes broadcasts on Twitch and Instagram will help take e-sports mainstream<br></p><p>The world’s largest computer game publisher, Activision Blizzard, is hoping to use Facebook’s live video to turn e-sports into a mainstream attraction, and make the people who play computer games competitively into the next sporting stars.</p><p>In New York on Thursday the company announced a slew of improvements to its e-sports platforms, which host video of competitive gamers playing titles such as Call of Duty or Starcraft. The company’s most popular event to date was the Major Championship of first-person shooter Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, which attracted 71m live and on-demand views. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/call-of-duty-infinite-warfare">Six reasons why everyone is hating on Call of Duty</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/call-of-duty-activision-facebook-esports-twitch-instagram">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>We are comfortable with a cartoon portrayal of Allies versus Nazis.       <description><p>The trailer for Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare title has been disliked more than a million times.     <item>
      <title>Uncharted 4 and the grief of finishing a great video game</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/uncharted-4-grief-finishing-video-game-loss-novel-tv</link>
      <description><p>A sense of loss often follows our reaching the end of a gripping novel or TV series, but in games our interaction with the characters can make the feeling deeper</p><p>When my son was coming to the end of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, having avidly consumed the previous six books in the series, his progress noticeably slowed. He’d go days, weeks even, before finishing a chapter – so much so that we thought that he was going off the story altogether. But he wasn’t. He was drawing it out. Like millions of other fans, he simply could not face leaving Hogwarts. Harry, Ron and Hermione had become more than characters: they were friends. He cried when he read the epilogue, “19 years later”.</p><p>This is a common phenomenon with very good books, and with television series too: the characters become so habitual and beloved over time that we form relationships with them, often augmented by the way we avidly discuss each instalment with friends and in online forums. In 2014, Cristel Russell, an associate professor at the American University’s Kogod School of Business, completed a study entitled When Narrative Brands End: The Impact of Narrative Closure and Consumption Sociality on Loss Accommodation, which argued that fans effectively go through a mourning process when a good show or book series comes to a close. We have to learn to let go.</p><p>Fans found it easier to move on from a show if there was definite, unambiguous closure</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/uncharted-4-grief-finishing-video-game-loss-novel-tv">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The addictive smartphone game has been shoehorned into an amusing animation narrative whose ridiculousness is part of its appeal</p><p>That’s right: a film has been made out of the addictive smartphone/tablet game Angry Birds, where catapults ping flightless birds at the little pink piggies who have stolen their eggs. This movie is driven by a naked commercial imperative – though perhaps no more than any other film – and it doesn’t match up to the hyperactive, clever surreality of the Lego Movie. Yet there is a kind of pleasure and fascination, mixed with exasperation, in seeing how the game has been mangled and bent into the shape of the conventional animation narrative, with zappy little dialogue moments, funny characters and some sophisticated touches for the grownups (including a nod to The Shining, of all things). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/the-angry-birds-movie-review-game-spin-off-that-doesnt-quite-reach-lego-movie-levels">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Here comes the Angry Birds film, but why can’t a game just be a game?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/07/here-comes-the-angry-birds-film-but-why-cant-a-game-just-be-a-game</link>
      <description>Big-screen adaptations of computer games, with A-list cameos, produce big cash. Some of it could be used to produce groundbreaking art<p>Back in 2009 a Finnish company called Rovio launched its 52nd video game. Its premise was simple: players would use their smartphone touchscreen – still a relative novelty two years after the first iPhone came out – to control a catapult. Swine flu was in the news, so the enemies would be pigs. The missiles? A flock of angry birds.</p><p>That game reportedly cost less than £100,000 to make. The numbers involved in <em>The Angry Birds Movie</em>, which arrives in cinemas 13 May, are rather larger. There’s an estimated $80m production budget and $100m set aside for marketing. Sony has even splashed out on the ultimate status symbol: an A-list cameo. Sean Penn, we were informed in April, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/07/dead-man-squawking-sean-penn-joining-angry-birds-movie" title="">will play a bird called Terence</a> who communicates only through low, rumbling growls.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/07/here-comes-the-angry-birds-film-but-why-cant-a-game-just-be-a-game">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The video game hall of famers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/ng-interactive/2016/may/07/the-video-game-hall-of-famers</link>
      <description><p>Space Invaders and Grand Theft Auto III recently joined the likes of Pong and Pac-Man in the World Video Game Hall of Fame. The history of these games is also the history of how we play them</p><p>The road from Space Invaders to Grand Theft Auto III is a long and winding one, but this week both were inducted into the World Video Game Hall of Fame. They join last year’s crop – Pong, Super Mario Bros, Pac-Man, Doom, World of Warcraft and Tetris – along with four other new inductees.</p><p>The history of those games is also the history of how we play them. Pac-Man, for example, was first released in the arcades in 1980. It went from PCs to Game Boys to consoles. And now it’s available on phones and tablets.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/ng-interactive/2016/may/07/the-video-game-hall-of-famers">Continue reading...</a></description>
